introduction.p: Now look at the third sequence of dots from the Investigate! activity. We will let a_n represent the number of dots in figure n\text{.} The sequence starts 1, 3, 6, 10,\ldots

statement.p: How many dots would you expect in the next two figures in the sequence?
Dots in n = 5 figure: a_5 =.
Dots in n = 6 figure: a_6 =.
Let a_n be the number of dots in figure n\text{.} Write a recursive definition for a_n\text{.}
a_n = ; with a_1 = .
Guess a closed formula for the number of dots in the nth figure.
a_n = .
Consider the sequence 4, 13, 22, 31, 40, \ldots with a_1 = 4.

li.p:
Which of the following is a recursive definition for the sequence. Select all that apply.
\(a_n = a_{n-1} + a_{n-2}\); \(a_1 = 4\)
\(a_n = 4 \cdot 9^n\)
\(a_n = a_{n-1} + 9\); \(a_1 = 4\)
\(a_n = 9 \cdot a_{n-1}\); \(a_1 = 4\)
Give a closed formula for the nth term of the sequence.

Is 4666 a term in the sequence?
No, it is between 4664 and 4673
Yes, it is \(a_{518}\)
No, it is larger than 1327
Yes, it is \(a_{4666}\)
Yes, it is \(a_{519}\)
How many terms does the finite sequence 4, 13, 22, 31, 40, \ldots, {1327} have?
Use what you found above to find b_n, the nth term of 1, {5}, {18}, {40}, {71}, \ldots where b_0 = 1.

solution.p: This is an arithmetic sequence with initial term 4 and common difference 9.
For the last part, you are finding the sequence of partial sums, added to 1.

statement.p: Consider the sequence (a_n)_{n \ge 0} which starts 7, 19, 31, 43, \ldots\text{.}

li.p: What is the next term in the sequence?
Find a formula for the nth term of this sequence.
Find the sum of the first 100 terms of the sequence: \sum_{k=0}^{99}a_k\text{.}
55\text{,} which is 43+12\text{.}
The sequence is arithmetic, with a_0 = 7 and constant difference 12, so a_n = 7 + 12n\text{.}
60100\text{.} We want 7 + 31 + \cdots + 1195\text{.} Reverse and add to get 100 sums of 1202, a total of 120200, which is twice the sum we are looking for.

statement.p: Consider the sum 8 + 17 + 26 + 35 + \cdots + 458\text{.}

li.p: How many terms (summands) are in the sum?
Compute the sum using a technique discussed in this section.

statement.p: Consider the sequence -11, 0, 11, 22, \ldots, 11n + 0\text{.}

li.p: How many terms are there in the sequence? Your answer will be in terms of n\text{.}
What is the second-to-last term?
Find the sum of all the terms in the sequence, in terms of n\text{.}
{n-\left(-1\right)+1} terms, since to get -11 using the formula 11n+0 we must use n=-1\text{.}
11n - 11\text{,} which is 11 less than 11n+0 (or plug in n-1 for n).
\frac{(11n - 11)*({n-\left(-1\right)+1})}{2}\text{.} Reverse and add. Each sum gives the constant 11n - 11 and there are {n-\left(-1\right)+1} terms.

statement.p: Find 12 + 24 + 36 + 48+ \cdots + 4152 using a technique from this section.

solution.p: 720372\text{.} If we take a_0 = 12\text{,} the terms of the sum are an arithmetic sequence with closed formula a_n = 12+12n\text{.} Then 4152 = a_{345}\text{,} for a total of 346 terms in the sum. Reverse and add to get 346 identical 4164 terms, which is twice the total we seek. 4164\cdot 346/2 = 720372

statement.p: Find 2 + 8 + 32 + \cdots + 2\cdot 4^{25}\text{.}

solution.p: \frac{2\cdot 4^{26}-2}{3}\text{.} Let the sum be S\text{,} and compute 4S - S = 3S\text{,} which causes terms except 2 and 2\cdot 4^{26} to cancel. Then solve for S\text{.}

statement.p: Find x and y such that 64, x, y, 1 is part of an arithmetic sequence.
x = , y =
Then find x and y so that the sequence is part of a geometric sequence.
x = , y =
(Warning: x and y might not be integers.)

solution.p: For arithmetic: x = 43\text{,} y = 22\text{.} For the arithmetic sequence, we know 64 + d = x\text{,} x + d = y\text{,} and y + d = 1\text{.} In other words, 64 + 3d = 1 so d = (-21)/3\text{.} For geometric: x = {16} and y = {4}\text{.} Similarly we can find the common ratio for the geometric sequence by solving 64\cdot r^3 = 1 for r\text{.}

statement.p: Find x and y such that 3, x, y, 36 is part of an arithmetic sequence.
x = , y =
Then find x and y so that the sequence is part of a geometric sequence.
x = , y =
(Warning: x and y might not be integers.)

solution.p: For arithmetic: x = 14 \text{,} y = 25 \text{.} We know that 3 + d = x\text{,} x + d = y\text{,} and y + d = 36\text{.} In other words, 3 + 3d = 36 so d = (33)/3\text{.}
For geometric: x = {6.86829} and y = {15.7244}\text{.} We can find the common ratio for the geometric sequence by solving 3\cdot r^3 = 36 for r\text{.}

statement.p: Use polynomial fitting to find the formula for the nth term of the sequence (a_n)_{n \ge 0} which starts,

solution.p: a_n = {2n^{2}-3n}\text{.} Here we know that we are looking for a quadratic because the second differences are constant. So a_n = an^2 + bn + c\text{.} Since a_0 = 0\text{,} we know c= 0\text{.} So just solve the system
to find a = 2 and b = -3.

statement.p: Use polynomial fitting to find the formula for the nth term of the sequence (a_n)_{n \ge 0} which starts,

solution.p: a_n = {2n^{2}+6n-5}\text{.} Here we know that we are looking for a quadratic because the second differences are constant. So a_n = an^2 + bn + c\text{.} Since a_0 = {-5} know c= {-5}\text{.} So just solve the system
to find a = {2} and b = {6}.

statement.p: Use polynomial fitting to find the formula for the nth term of the sequence (a_n)_{n \ge 0} which starts,

solution.p: a_n = {3n^{3}+2n+1}\text{.} Here we know that we are looking for a cubic because the third differences are constant. So a_n = an^3 + bn^2 + cn + d\text{.} Since a_0 = {1} know d= {1}\text{.} So just solve the system
to find a = {3}, b = 0, and c = {2}.

statement.p: Use polynomial fitting to find the formula for the nth term of the sequence (a_n)_{n \ge 1} which starts,
{8, 24, 68, 158, 312}, \ldots Note the first term above is a_1, not a_0.

solution.p: a_n = {3n^{3}-4n^{2}+7n+2}\text{.} Here we know that we are looking for a cubic because the third differences are constant. So a_n = an^3 + bn^2 + cn + d\text{.} We can work backwards to find that a_0 = {2}, so we know d= {2}\text{.} Then solve the system,
to find a = {3}, b = {-4}, and c = {7}.

statement.p: Suppose Suppose a_n = {3n^{2}+6n-1}\text{.} Find a closed formula for the sequence of differences by computing a_n - a_{n-1}\text{.} Simplify your answer as much as posible.

solution.p: a_{n-1} = (n-1)^2 + 6(n-1) - 1 = {3n^{2}-4}\text{.} Thus a_n - a_{n-1} = {6n+3}\text{.} Note that this is linear (arithmetic).

statement.p: Use polynomial fitting to find the formula for the nth term of the sequence (a_n)_{n \ge 1} which starts,
{8, 26, 60, 116, 200}, \ldots Note the first term above is a_1, not a_0.

solution.p: a_n = {n^{3}+2n^{2}+5n}\text{.} Here we know that we are looking for a cubic because the third differences are constant. So a_n = an^3 + bn^2 + cn + d\text{.} We can work backwards to find that a_0 = {0}, so we know d= {0}\text{.} Then solve the system,
to find a = {1}, b = {2}, and c = {5}.

statement.p: Solve the recurrence relation a_n = a_{n-1} + 2^n with a_0 = -1\text{.}

solution.p: a_n = -3 + 2^{n+1}\text{.} We should use telescoping or iteration here. For example, telescoping gives

p.m: \displaystyle{\newcommand{\amp}{\amp }\begin{aligned} a_1 - a_0 \amp = 2^1\\ a_2 - a_1 \amp = 2^2\\ a_3 - a_2 \amp = 2^3\\ \vdots\amp \vdots \\ a_n - a_{n-1} \amp = 2^n \end{aligned}}

solution.p: which sums to a_n - a_0 = 2^{n+1} - 2 (using the multiply-shift-subtract technique for the geometric series on the right-hand side). Substituting a_0 = -1 and solving for a_n completes the solution.

statement.p: Find the solution to the recurrence relation a_n = 2a_{n-1} + 15a_{n-2} with initial terms a_0 = {2} and a_1 = {2}\text{.}

solution.p: By the Characteristic Root Technique. a_n = {\left(-3\right)^{n}+5^{n}}\text{.}

statement.p: Find the solution to the recurrence relation a_n = 5a_{n-1} + 14a_{n-2} with initial terms a_0 = {2} and a_1 = {5}\text{.}
Find the solution to the recurrence relation b_n = 5b_{n-1} + 14b_{n-2} with initial terms b_0 = 2 and b_1 = {16}\text{.}

solution.p: The characteristic roots for both sequences are -2 and 7 (since the two sequence have the same recurrence relation, they have the same characteristic roots). Solving the for coefficients in each case gives the closed formulas. We have a_n = {\left(-2\right)^{n}+7^{n}} and b_n = {\left({\frac{20}{9}}\right)\cdot 7^{n}-\left({\frac{2}{9}}\right)\!\left(-2\right)^{n}}.

statement.p: Find the solution to the recurrence relation a_n = 5a_{n-1} + 14a_{n-2} with initial terms a_0 = 8 and a_1 = 20\text{.}

solution.p: By the Characteristic Root Technique. a_n = {4\!\left(-2\right)^{n}+4\cdot 7^{n}}\text{.}

statement.p: Find 7 + 15 + 23+ \cdots + 1991\text{.}
Consider the sequence -9, 1, 11, 21, \ldots, 10n + 1\text{.}

li.p: How many terms are there in the sequence?
What is the second-to-last term?
Find the sum of all the terms in the sequence.
{n-\left(-1\right)} terms.

statement.p: Consider the sequence given by a_n = 6\cdot 2^{n-1}\text{.}

li.p: Find the first 4 terms of the sequence.
What sort of sequence is this?
arithmetic
geometric
neither
Find the sum of the first 33 terms. That is, compute \sum_{k=1}^{33}a_k\text{.}
6, 12, 24, 48, \ldots The sequence is geometric.

statement.p: Use polynomial fitting to find the formula for the nth term of the sequence (a_n)_{n \ge 1} which starts,
{13, 24, 37, 52, 69}, \ldots Note the first term above is a_1, not a_0.

solution.p: a_n = {n^{2}+8n+4}\text{.} Here we know that we are looking for a quadratic because the second differences are constant. So a_n = an^2 + bn + c\text{.} We can work backwards to find that a_0 = {4}, so we know c= {4}\text{.} Then solve the system,
to find a = {1} and b = {8}.

statement.p: The sequence (a_n)_{n \ge 1} starts -1, 0, 2, 5, 9, 14\ldots and has closed formula a_n = \dfrac{(n+1)(n-2)}{2}\text{.} Use this fact to find a closed formula for the sequence (b_n)_{n \ge 1} which starts 4, 10, 18, 28, 40, \ldots\text{.}

solution.p: The sequence is 9, 12, {288}, {1200}, {11664}, \ldots. It has closed formula a_n = {\left({\frac{51}{11}}\right)\!\left(-4\right)^{n}+\left({\frac{48}{11}}\right)\cdot 7^{n}}, using the characteristic root technique.

The sequence is 4, 7, {112}, {595}, {4732}, \ldots. It has closed formula a_n = {\left({\frac{21}{10}}\right)\!\left(-3\right)^{n}+\left({\frac{19}{10}}\right)\cdot 7^{n}}, using the characteristic root technique.

statement.p: A = {\left\{2,4,5,6,7\right\}}\text{ and } B = {\left\{2,4,5,6,8\right\}} Find each of the following sets.
Your answers should include the curly braces

li.p: A \cup B = {\left\{2,4,5,6,7,8\right\}}\text{.} It includes everything that is in A or B or both.
A \cap B = {\left\{2,4,5,6\right\}}\text{.} It contains everything that is in both A and B\text{.}
A \setminus B = {\left\{7\right\}}\text{.} It contains everything that is in A except anything that is also in B\text{.} We could also have written this set as A \cap \bar{B}\text{.}

B \setminus A = {\left\{8\right\}}\text{.} It contains everything in B except anything that is also in A\text{.} Another way to write this is B \cap \bar{A}\text{.} Note that A \setminus B \ne B \setminus A\text{.}

statement.p: Find the least element of each of the following sets, if there is one.
If there is no least element, enter none.

li.p: \renewcommand{\d}{\displaystyle}\newcommand{\N}{\mathbb N}\newcommand{\st}{:}\{n \in \N \st n^2 - 3 \ge 5\}\text{.} .

p.m: \renewcommand{\d}{\displaystyle}\newcommand{\N}{\mathbb N}\newcommand{\st}{:}\{n \in \N \st n = k^2 + 1 \text{ for some } k \in \N\}\text{.}

li.p: This is the set \{3, 4, 5 \ldots \} since we need each element to be a natural number whose square is at least 3 more than 5. Since 3^2 - 3 = 6 but 2^2 - 3 = 1 we see that the first such natural number is 3.
We get the same set as we did in the previous part, and the smallest non-negative number for which n^2 - 8 is a natural number is 3.
Note that if we didnt specify n \ge 0 by saying that n \in \mathbb N then any integer less than -3 would also be in the set, so there would not be a least element.

This is the set \{1, 2, 5, 10, \ldots\}\text{,} namely the set of numbers that are the result of squaring and adding 1 to a natural number. (0^2 + 1 = 1\text{,} 1^2 + 1 = 2\text{,} 2^2 + 1 = 5 and so on.) Thus the least element of the set is 1.

Now we are looking for natural numbers that are equal to taking some natural number, squaring it and adding 1. That is, \{1, 2, 5, 10, \ldots\}\text{,} the same set as the previous part. So again, the least element is 1.
27 = 30 - 4 + 1. We need to add one in order to count 4 itself.
There are 8 primes not greater than 22: {\left\{2,3,5,7,11,13,17,19\right\}}\text{.}

solution.p: The set of largest size that is a subset of both A \text{ and } B is the intersection of A \text{ and } B \text{,} A \cap B = {\left\{8\right\}}\text{.}

statement.p: Find a set of smallest possible size that has both {4,6,9} and {2,3,4,9} as subsets.

solution.p: For C \subseteq A and C \subseteq B\text{,} we must have that C \subseteq A \cap B\text{.} This means that the largest C could be would be to equal \newcommand{\N}{\mathbb N}\newcommand{\st}{:}A \cap B = \{n \in \N \st 39 \le n \le 46\}\text{,} which contains 8 elements.

statement.p: Let A = {\left\{0,2,7,13,14\right\}} and B = {\left\{0,2,14\right\}}\text{.} How many sets C have the property that C \subseteq A and B \subseteq C\text{.}

hint.p: You should be able to write all of them out. Dont forget A and B\text{,} which are also candidates for C\text{.}

solution.p: There will be exactly 4 such sets: {\left\{0,2,14\right\}}\text{,}{\left\{0,2,7,14\right\}}\text{,} {\left\{0,2,13,14\right\}}\text{,} and {\left\{0,2,7,13,14\right\}}\text{.}

statement.p: Let A = {\left\{2,3,4,5,6\right\}}\text{,} B = {\left\{4,5,6,7,8\right\}}\text{,} and C = {\left\{3,6,8\right\}}\text{.}

li.p: Find A \cap B\text{.}
Find A \cup B\text{.}
Find A \setminus B\text{.}
Find A \cap \overline{(B \cup C)}\text{.}
Find A \cap B\text{.}
Find A \setminus B\text{.}

A \cap B will be the set of natural numbers that are both at least 2 and less than 16, and even. That is, \renewcommand{\d}{\displaystyle}\newcommand{\N}{\mathbb N}\newcommand{\st}{:}\renewcommand{\v}{\vtx{above}{}}A \cap B = \{x \in \N \st 2 \le x \lt 16 \wedge x \text{ is even}\} = {\left\{2,4,6,8,10,12,14\right\}}\text{.}

A \setminus B is the set of all elements that are in A but not B\text{.} So this is \renewcommand{\d}{\displaystyle}\newcommand{\N}{\mathbb N}\newcommand{\st}{:}\renewcommand{\v}{\vtx{above}{}}\{x \in \N \st 2 \le x \lt 16 \wedge x \text{ is odd}\} = {\left\{3,5,7,9,11,13,15\right\}}\text{.}
Note this is the same set as A \cap \overline{B}\text{.}

statement.p: Let A = \{1,2,\ldots, 9\}\text{.} How many subsets of A contain exactly one element (i.e., how many singleton subsets are there)?
How many doubleton subsets (containing exactly two elements) are there?

hint.p: Write these out, or at least start to and look for a pattern.

solution.p: Each of the 9 elements can be in a singleton set, so there are 9 of these.

To count the number of doubletons, not that there are 8 sets that include 1, and then 7 sets that include 2 and not 1, and then 6 that include 3 and not 1 or 2, and so on. So you can find 36 by summing the numbers from 1 to 8.

statement.p:
Let A = \{2, 4, 6, 8\}\text{.} Suppose B is a set with |B| = 5\text{.}
What are the smallest and largest possible values of |A \cup B|\text{?} Explain.
What are the smallest and largest possible values of |A \cap B|\text{?} Explain.
What are the smallest and largest possible values of |A \times B|\text{?} Explain.
Consider the function f:\{1,2,3,4,5\} \to \{1,2,3,4,5\} given by

li.p: Find f(5).
Find a n in the domain such that f(n) = 5\text{.}
Find an element n of the domain such that f(n) = n\text{.}
Find an element of the codomain that is not in the range.
f(5) = 1\text{,} since 1 is the number below 5 in the two-line notation.
Such an n is n= 3\text{,} since f(3) = 5\text{.} Note that 3 is above a 5 in the notation.
n = 2 has this property. We say that 2 is a fixed point of f\text{.} Not all functions have such a point.
Such an element is 3 (in fact, that is the only element in the codomain that is not in the range). In other words, 3 is not the image of any element under f\text{;} nothing is sent to 3.

statement.p: The following functions all have \lbrace 1,2,3,4,5\rbrace as both their domain and codomain. For each, determine whether it is (only) injective, (only) surjective, bijective, or neither injective nor surjective.

hint.p: Since the domain and codomain are the same size, is it possible for a function to be injective but not surjective, or surjective but not injective?

statement.p: Consider the following functions f: \lbrace 1,2,3,4,5\rbrace \to \lbrace 1,2,3\rbrace. For each, determine whether it is (only) injective, (only) surjective, bijective, or neither injective nor surjective.

p.m: f(x) = \begin{cases} 4-x \amp \text{ if } x \le 3 \\ x-3 \amp \text{ if } x > 3 \end{cases}

statement.p: Consider the following functions f: \lbrace 1,2,3,4\rbrace \to \lbrace 1,2,3,4,5\rbrace. For each, determine whether it is (only) injective, (only) surjective, bijective, or neither injective nor surjective.
Write out all functions f: \{1,2,3,4\} \to \{a,b\} (using two-line notation).
How many functions are there?
How many are surjective?
How many are injective?
How many are bijective?

solution.p: There are 16 different functions. None of the functions are injective. Exactly 14 of the functions are surjective (there are 2 that are not: send everything to a or everything to b. No functions are both (since no functions here are injective).

statement.p: Write out all functions f: \{1,2\} \to \{a,b,c,d\} (in two-line notation).
How many functions are there?
How many are surjective?
How many are injective?
How many are bijective?

solution.p: There are 16 functions: you have a choice of four outputs for f(1)\text{,} and for each, you have four choices for the output f(2)\text{.} Of these functions, 12 are injective, 0 are surjective, and 0 are both (i.e., bijective):

statement.p: Consider the function \renewcommand{\d}{\displaystyle}\newcommand{\N}{\mathbb N} f:\N \to \N given recursively by f(0) = 1 and f(n+1) = 3 \cdot f(n) \text{.} Find f(14) \text{.}

solution.p: f(14) = 4782969\text{.} To find f(14)\text{,} we need to know f(13)\text{,} for which we need f(12)\text{,} and so on. So build up from f(0) = 1\text{.} Then f(1) = 3\text{,} f(2) = 3\cdot3\text{,} f(3) = 3\cdot3\cdot3\text{,} .... In fact, it looks like a closed formula for f is f(n) = 3^n\text{.} Later we will see how to prove this is correct.
